data.origin: Middle English, from Old French amender

definitions.definition: To make minor changes to improve or clarify
definitions.example: The committee voted to amend the proposal.

definitions.definition: A concise statement of a principle
definitions.example: The saying 'less is more' is a famous aphorism.

data.origin: Early 20th century, from Latin audire 'to hear'

definitions.definition: Sound, especially when recorded or reproduced
definitions.example: The film's audio was exceptionally clear.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin autumnus

definitions.definition: The season between summer and winter
definitions.example: The leaves change color in autumn.

data.origin: Middle English, imitative of bubbling sound

definitions.definition: A thin sphere of liquid enclosing air
definitions.example: Children love blowing soap bubbles.

definitions.definition: To form bubbles
definitions.example: The boiling water began to bubble.

data.origin: Old English brycg, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: A structure carrying a road across a river
definitions.example: They walked across the old stone bridge.

definitions.definition: To make a connection between two things
definitions.example: The program bridges the gap between education and employment.

definitions.definition: A person's regular occupation or trade
definitions.example: She runs a successful catering business.

data.origin: Middle English quer, quere, from Old French

definitions.definition: An organized group of singers
definitions.example: The church choir performs every Sunday.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin collegium

definitions.definition: An educational institution
definitions.example: She attends college in Boston.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French compas

definitions.definition: An instrument for determining direction
definitions.example: The hiker used a compass to navigate.

definitions.definition: An event in which people compete
definitions.example: She won first prize in the singing contest.

definitions.definition: To oppose or challenge
definitions.example: He decided to contest the will in court.

data.origin: Old English cradol, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: A baby's bed on rockers
definitions.example: The mother rocked the cradle gently.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French

definitions.definition: A person who is descended from a particular ancestor
definitions.example: She is a descendant of the original settlers.

definitions.definition: A sudden event causing great damage
definitions.example: The earthquake was a natural disaster.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from medieval Latin dies mali 'evil days'

definitions.definition: Causing or showing gloom
definitions.example: The weather was dismal all week.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French desobeir

definitions.definition: To refuse to follow orders
definitions.example: The soldier chose to disobey the command.

data.origin: Mid 17th century, from Latin elevare 'to raise'

definitions.definition: A platform or compartment for raising people or goods
definitions.example: We took the elevator to the 10th floor.

definitions.definition: Information indicating whether something is true
definitions.example: The fingerprints were important evidence.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin exportare

definitions.definition: To send goods to another country for sale
definitions.example: The company exports cars to Europe.

definitions.definition: Goods sent to another country
definitions.example: Coffee is one of Brazil's main exports.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French fausset

definitions.definition: A device controlling water flow from a pipe
definitions.example: He turned the faucet to get a glass of water.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French fontaine

definitions.definition: An ornamental structure sending water into the air
definitions.example: The park's fountain was lit up at night.

data.origin: Old English freond, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: People with whom one has a bond of mutual affection
definitions.example: They have been best friends since childhood.

data.origin: Old English gōs, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: A large waterbird with a long neck
definitions.example: A flock of geese flew overhead.

data.origin: Old English hamor, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: A tool with a heavy metal head mounted at right angles at the end of a handle
definitions.example: He used a hammer to drive the nail into the wall.

definitions.definition: To hit or beat something with a hammer or similar object
definitions.example: She hammered the metal into shape.

definitions.definition: An establishment providing accommodation and meals
definitions.example: They stayed at a luxury hotel in Paris.

definitions.definition: Contrary to or forbidden by law
definitions.example: Parking in front of the hydrant is illegal.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French joel

definitions.definition: A precious stone
definitions.example: The crown was set with valuable jewels.

definitions.definition: Used to express uncertainty or possibility
definitions.example: Perhaps we should leave early to avoid traffic.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from pine + apple

definitions.definition: A tropical fruit with sweet yellow flesh
definitions.example: She cut up a fresh pineapple for dessert.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French poison

definitions.definition: A substance causing death or harm
definitions.example: The label warned that the bottle contained poison.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin salutare

definitions.definition: A gesture of respect or greeting
definitions.example: The soldier gave a sharp salute.

definitions.definition: To make a formal gesture of respect
definitions.example: The officer saluted as the general passed.

definitions.definition: A person or thing being discussed
definitions.example: The subject of the lecture was climate change.

definitions.definition: The accomplishment of an aim
definitions.example: The project's success surprised everyone.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin tutor

definitions.definition: A private teacher
definitions.example: She hired a math tutor for extra help.

definitions.definition: To act as a tutor
definitions.example: He tutored her in French.

definitions.definition: A distinguishing quality or characteristic
definitions.example: Honesty is one of her best traits.

definitions.definition: To make a thorough or dramatic change
definitions.example: The renovation transformed the old building.

data.origin: Old English word, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: A single distinct meaningful element of speech
definitions.example: She couldn't think of the right word.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Low German wrangeln

definitions.definition: To have a long, complicated dispute
definitions.example: The lawyers wrangled over the contract details.

data.origin: Old English nō, nā, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: Used to give a negative response
definitions.example: When asked if he was tired, he said no.

data.origin: Old English gēse, probably from gēa 'yes' + sīe 'may it be'

definitions.definition: Used to give an affirmative response
definitions.example: When offered more coffee, she said yes.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from may + be

definitions.definition: Perhaps; possibly
definitions.example: Maybe we'll go to the beach tomorrow.

data.origin: Old English cild, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: A young human being below the age of puberty
definitions.example: The children played in the park.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French forrer

definitions.definition: The short, fine, soft hair of certain animals
definitions.example: The cat's fur was silky smooth.

data.origin: Old English lufu, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: An intense feeling of deep affection
definitions.example: The mother's love for her child was evident.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French departir

definitions.definition: To leave, especially to start a journey
definitions.example: The train will depart at 3:15 pm.

definitions.definition: In opposition to
definitions.example: They voted against the proposal.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from French ample

definitions.definition: Enough or more than enough
definitions.example: There was ample evidence to convict him.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French bacin

definitions.definition: A bowl for washing
definitions.example: She filled the basin with warm water.

definitions.definition: To comfort someone in distress
definitions.example: He tried to console his crying child.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French fieble

definitions.definition: Lacking physical strength
definitions.example: The old man's voice was feeble.

definitions.definition: An experienced adviser
definitions.example: She served as a mentor to young lawyers.

definitions.definition: A person or group maintaining order
definitions.example: The security patrol walked around the building.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin secretarius

definitions.definition: A person employed to handle correspondence
definitions.example: The secretary scheduled all the meetings.

data.origin: Middle English, from Anglo-Norman French taillour

definitions.definition: A person who makes clothes
definitions.example: The tailor measured him for a new suit.

data.origin: Old English thōht, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: Ideas or opinions produced by thinking
definitions.example: She shared her thoughts on the matter.

definitions.definition: A medium-sized sailboat
definitions.example: They sailed their yacht around the bay.

definitions.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning
definitions.example: The politician's ambiguous statement left reporters confused.

definitions.definition: Unclear or inexact because a choice between alternatives has not been made
definitions.example: The test results were ambiguous and required further analysis.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin abhorrere

definitions.definition: To regard with disgust
definitions.example: She abhors violence in any form.

definitions.definition: Inspiring disgust and loathing
definitions.example: The idea of cheating was abhorrent to him.

definitions.definition: To provide lodging or space
definitions.example: The hotel can accommodate 200 guests.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin accident-

definitions.definition: By chance; unintentionally
definitions.example: She accidentally deleted the important file.

definitions.definition: A collection of things that have been gathered
definitions.example: The report was an aggregation of various studies.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French ele

definitions.definition: A passage between rows of seats
definitions.example: Please don't block the aisle with your bags.

definitions.definition: A person who engages in a pursuit on an unpaid basis
definitions.example: The competition was open to both professionals and amateurs.

definitions.definition: Comparable in certain respects
definitions.example: The wings of birds and bats are analogous structures.

definitions.definition: Deviating from what is standard or expected
definitions.example: The anomalous results puzzled the researchers.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French antiquite

definitions.definition: The ancient past
definitions.example: The museum displayed artifacts from classical antiquity.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French aprochier

definitions.definition: To come near or nearer to
definitions.example: We could see the storm approaching.

definitions.definition: A way of dealing with something
definitions.example: The teacher tried a new approach to the lesson.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin artificium

definitions.definition: Clever or cunning tricks
definitions.example: The magician's performance was full of artifice.

definitions.definition: A heat-resistant fibrous mineral
definitions.example: The old building contained asbestos insulation.

data.origin: Old English on sundran 'in or into a separate place'

definitions.definition: Apart
definitions.example: The ship was torn asunder by the storm.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin austerus

definitions.definition: Sternness or severity of manner
definitions.example: The austerity of the monk's life was challenging.

definitions.definition: Very strange or unusual
definitions.example: She wore a bizarre costume to the party.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French blasphemie

definitions.definition: Profane talk about sacred things
definitions.example: The priest condemned the book as blasphemy.

definitions.definition: A bold manner intended to impress
definitions.example: His bravado hid his nervousness.

definitions.definition: A person or thing that spoils enjoyment
definitions.example: His negative comments were a real buzzkill.

definitions.definition: A sweet, chewy candy
definitions.example: She drizzled caramel over the apples.

definitions.definition: To reprimand severely
definitions.example: The teacher castigated the cheating student.

definitions.definition: An event causing great damage
definitions.example: The earthquake was a natural catastrophe.

data.origin: Late 19th century, from Latin claustrum 'lock' + phobia

definitions.definition: Fear of confined spaces
definitions.example: Her claustrophobia made elevators difficult.

definitions.definition: Kept secret or done secretly
definitions.example: They held clandestine meetings in the basement.

definitions.definition: To fall down suddenly
definitions.example: The old building collapsed in the storm.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from medieval Latin collateralis

definitions.definition: Something pledged as security for repayment
definitions.example: He used his house as collateral for the loan.

definitions.definition: Relating to abstract ideas
definitions.example: The artist presented a conceptual framework.

definitions.definition: An inner feeling of right and wrong
definitions.example: His conscience wouldn't let him cheat.

definitions.definition: Forming an unbroken whole
definitions.example: The road was under continuous construction.

definitions.definition: In excellent order
definitions.example: Everything was copacetic at the office.

data.origin: Early 16th century, from Latin cornu copiae

definitions.definition: An abundant supply
definitions.example: The festival offered a cornucopia of food.

definitions.definition: Longer than the most direct way
definitions.example: We took a circuitous route to avoid traffic.

definitions.definition: The action of describing precisely
definitions.example: The report contained a clear delineation of responsibilities.

definitions.definition: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to desires rather than reason
definitions.example: The dictator was a dangerous demagogue.

definitions.definition: The number below the line in a fraction
definitions.example: In the fraction 3/4, 4 is the denominator.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French desirer

definitions.definition: Worth having or wanting
definitions.example: The house had many desirable features.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French

definitions.definition: The action of ending something
definitions.example: The discontinuance of the service angered customers.

definitions.definition: Having intervals or gaps
definitions.example: The path was discontinuous and hard to follow.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French desparagier

definitions.definition: To regard as being of little worth
definitions.example: He disparaged their efforts as amateurish.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin distractio(n-)

definitions.definition: A thing that prevents concentration
definitions.example: The noise outside was a constant distraction.

data.origin: Mid 16th century, from medieval Latin eccentricitas

definitions.definition: The quality of being unconventional
definitions.example: Her eccentricity made her a local legend.

definitions.definition: The action of enclosing in a capsule
definitions.example: The encapsulation process preserves the flavor.

definitions.definition: The action of giving support
definitions.example: Your kind words gave me the encouragement I needed.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from phrase put oneself in devoir

definitions.definition: An attempt to achieve something
definitions.example: The scientific endeavor took years of work.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French entreprise

definitions.definition: A project or undertaking
definitions.example: The business was a risky enterprise.

definitions.definition: A widespread occurrence of disease
definitions.example: The city faced a flu epidemic last winter.

definitions.definition: A state of physical balance
definitions.example: The gymnast maintained perfect equilibrium.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French establiss-

definitions.definition: To set up on a firm basis
definitions.example: They established a new business in the city.

definitions.definition: A feeling of intense excitement
definitions.example: Winning the championship filled them with euphoria.

definitions.definition: Making one feel very happy
definitions.example: The roller coaster ride was exhilarating.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French exercice

definitions.definition: Activity requiring physical effort
definitions.example: Regular exercise improves your health.

definitions.definition: Spoken or done without preparation
definitions.example: His extemporaneous speech impressed the audience.

definitions.definition: A complete failure
definitions.example: The product launch was a total fiasco.

definitions.definition: Glowing as a result of light absorption
definitions.example: The fluorescent paint glowed under black light.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin fraudulentus

definitions.definition: Obtained by deception
definitions.example: The company was accused of fraudulent practices.

definitions.definition: A musical instrument with tuned metal bars
definitions.example: The percussionist played the glockenspiel.

definitions.definition: An attractive quality
definitions.example: The actress brought glamour to the event.

definitions.definition: Relating to visual art
definitions.example: She studied graphic design in college.

definitions.definition: Comically or repulsively ugly
definitions.example: The statue had grotesque facial features.

data.origin: Late 18th century, named after Dr. Joseph-Ignace Guillotin

definitions.definition: A device for beheading people
definitions.example: The guillotine was used during the French Revolution.

definitions.definition: Lacking originality
definitions.example: The speech was full of hackneyed phrases.

definitions.definition: Lacking any obvious principle
definitions.example: The books were arranged in a haphazard manner.

definitions.definition: Looking exhausted
definitions.example: After the long journey, his face was haggard.

definitions.definition: Problem-solving techniques
definitions.example: The software used heuristics to detect patterns.

data.origin: Middle English, via Old French and Latin from Greek hierarkhia

definitions.definition: A system of ranking
definitions.example: The company had a strict hierarchy.

data.origin: Late Middle English, alteration of hotchpotch

definitions.definition: A confused mixture
definitions.example: The soup was a hodgepodge of leftovers.

definitions.definition: Words having the same spelling but different meanings
definitions.example: 'Bat' (animal) and 'bat' (sports equipment) are homonyms.

data.origin: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin humilis ‘low, lowly’.

definitions.definition: Having or showing a modest or low estimate of one's own importance.
definitions.example: He was humble about his achievements despite his fame.

definitions.definition: To lower (someone) in dignity or importance.
definitions.example: She humbled her opponent with a flawless victory.

definitions.definition: Exemption from punishment or freedom from consequences.
definitions.example: The corrupt officials acted with impunity for years.

definitions.definition: Having or showing no skill; clumsy.
definitions.example: His inept handling of the situation made things worse.

definitions.definition: The fact or state of being independent.
definitions.example: The country celebrated 50 years of independence.

definitions.definition: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
definitions.example: The accident was the inevitable result of reckless driving.

definitions.definition: The basic physical systems of a country or organization.
definitions.example: The city invested in modernizing its transportation infrastructure.

definitions.definition: The ability to assess and initiate things independently.
definitions.example: She showed great initiative by solving the problem without being asked.

definitions.definition: Insisting or demanding something; not allowing refusal.
definitions.example: He was insistent that we arrive on time.

definitions.definition: Rude and disrespectful behavior.
definitions.example: The student was punished for his insolence toward the teacher.

data.origin: Medieval Latin intuitivus, from Latin intueri ‘consider’.

definitions.definition: Using or based on what one feels to be true without conscious reasoning.
definitions.example: She had an intuitive understanding of the problem.

definitions.definition: A written or verbal request inviting someone to go somewhere or to do something.
definitions.example: She received an invitation to the wedding.

data.origin: Latin jovialis ‘of Jupiter’ (the planet associated with joy).

definitions.definition: Cheerful and friendly.
definitions.example: His jovial manner made him popular at parties.

definitions.definition: A country, state, or territory ruled by a king or queen.
definitions.example: The United Kingdom consists of four nations.

definitions.definition: A plot or scheme.
definitions.example: The villain's machinations were finally exposed.

definitions.definition: To enroll at a college or university.
definitions.example: She matriculated at Harvard last fall.

definitions.definition: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
definitions.example: The artist was meticulous in her brushwork.

definitions.definition: To interpret incorrectly.
definitions.example: They misunderstood the instructions and got lost.

definitions.definition: An important or powerful person, especially in the film or media industry.
definitions.example: The Hollywood mogul greenlit the blockbuster.

definitions.definition: The least or smallest amount or quantity possible.
definitions.example: The minimum age for voting is 18.

definitions.definition: Smallest or lowest.
definitions.example: The minimum wage was recently increased.

definitions.definition: Existing in name only.
definitions.example: The nominal leader had no real power.

definitions.definition: (of a price or fee) very small.
definitions.example: A nominal charge was applied for the service.

definitions.definition: Easily seen or noticed; clear or apparent.
definitions.example: There was a noticeable improvement in her performance.

definitions.definition: In a formal or authoritative manner.
definitions.example: The law was officially enacted yesterday.

definitions.definition: A playful or invented term with no standard definition.
definitions.example: The children giggled at the silly word 'oogashaka'.

definitions.definition: The formation of a word from a sound associated with what is named (e.g., buzz, hiss).
definitions.example: "Boom" is an example of onomatopoeia.

definitions.definition: The action of making the best or most effective use of a situation or resource.
definitions.example: The optimization of the website improved loading speeds.

definitions.definition: Present or existing from the beginning; first or earliest.
definitions.example: The original manuscript was carefully preserved.

definitions.definition: The earliest form of something, from which copies may be made.
definitions.example: The portrait was a copy, not the original.

definitions.definition: Wild and noisy disorder or confusion; uproar.
definitions.example: Pandemonium broke out when the concert tickets went on sale.

definitions.definition: A cloth canopy that allows a person or object to descend slowly when dropped from a height.
definitions.example: The skydiver checked his parachute before jumping.

definitions.definition: To drop or descend using a parachute.
definitions.example: Supplies were parachuted into the disaster zone.

definitions.definition: To analyze (a sentence) into its parts and describe their syntactic roles.
definitions.example: The student parsed the complex Latin sentence.

data.origin: Old French perillous, from Latin periculosus.

definitions.definition: Full of danger or risk.
definitions.example: The climbers faced a perilous journey up the icy peak.

definitions.definition: A magazine or newspaper published at regular intervals.
definitions.example: The library subscribes to several scientific periodicals.

definitions.definition: A raised level surface on which people or things can stand.
definitions.example: The speaker stepped onto the platform.

data.origin: Old French pleit, from Latin plicitum ‘a fold’.

definitions.definition: Folded into pleats.
definitions.example: She wore a pleated skirt to the party.

data.origin: Old French, literally ‘pricking’, from Latin pungere ‘to prick’.

definitions.definition: Evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret.
definitions.example: The poignant letter brought tears to her eyes.

definitions.definition: All the inhabitants of a particular area.
definitions.example: The population of the city has grown over the past decade.

data.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘progeny’), from Latin posteritas.

definitions.definition: All future generations of people.
definitions.example: They preserved the documents for posterity.

data.origin: Late Latin praecōx, from prae‑ ‘early’ + coquere ‘to ripen’.

definitions.definition: Having developed certain abilities or inclinations at an earlier age than usual.
definitions.example: She was a precocious child who read books meant for adults.

definitions.definition: Related to an established or official way of doing something.
definitions.example: The court ruled that there had been a procedural error.

data.origin: Late Middle English: from Old French professionnel or Latin professionalis ‘belonging to a profession’.

definitions.definition: A person engaged in a profession, especially one requiring advanced training.
definitions.example: She’s a marketing professional with over 10 years’ experience.

definitions.definition: Relating to or connected with a profession.
definitions.example: He received professional training in graphic design.

data.origin: Late Middle English: from Latin profanus ‘outside the temple’.

definitions.definition: Not relating to religious or spiritual matters; secular.
definitions.example: His profane language offended some listeners.

definitions.definition: A mechanical device that rotates to propel a vehicle or vessel.
definitions.example: The ship’s propeller cut through the water.

data.origin: Late Middle English: from Old French prosperus or medieval Latin prosperosus.

definitions.definition: Successful in material terms; flourishing financially.
definitions.example: They built a prosperous business together.

data.origin: Early 1600s, said to be alteration of rascal.

definitions.definition: A mischievous person, especially a child.
definitions.example: That little rapscallion is always up to something.

data.origin: Late Middle English: from Latin receptor ‘receiver’.

definitions.definition: A cell or device that receives stimuli.
definitions.example: The nerve receptor sends signals to the brain.

definitions.definition: In a way that shows a lack of care or regard for danger.
definitions.example: He drove recklessly during the storm.

data.origin: Late Middle English: from Old French rehercier ‘go over again’.

definitions.definition: Practice or trial performance of a play or piece before the final public performance.
definitions.example: We had a rehearsal before opening night.

data.origin: Late Middle English: from re‑ + forcer ‘to strengthen’.

definitions.definition: Strengthen or support (an object or substance), especially with additional personnel or material.
definitions.example: They reinforced the bridge with steel beams.

data.origin: Late 19th century: French, from renaître ‘be reborn’.

definitions.definition: A revival of art and literature under the influence of classical models.
definitions.example: The Renaissance in Italy produced artists like Leonardo.

data.origin: Late Middle English: from re‑ + placement.

definitions.definition: The action or process of replacing someone or something.
definitions.example: The broken parts were sent for replacement.

data.origin: Middle English: from Old French resist-, from Latin resistere ‘stand back’.

definitions.definition: To withstand the action or effect of.
definitions.example: She couldn’t resist the temptation.

data.origin: Mid 16th century: from Latin retention- ‘a keeping’, from retinēre ‘to hold back’.

definitions.definition: The continued possession, use, or control of something.
definitions.example: Employee retention is crucial for companies.

data.origin: Early 19th century: from Latin reticent‑, from reticēre ‘be silent’.

definitions.definition: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily.
definitions.example: He was reticent about his personal life.

definitions.definition: Able to be used more than once.
definitions.example: We prefer reusable water bottles.

data.origin: Late Middle English: from Latin ruminat- ‘chewed over’, from rumināre.

definitions.definition: Deep or considered thoughts about something.
definitions.example: His ruminations on life were very profound.

data.origin: Old English sæl ‘time, occasion’, later sense ‘the act of selling’.

definitions.definition: The exchange of a commodity for money; the amount sold.
definitions.example: Our sales increased this quarter.

data.origin: Mid 16th century: from Latin salutatio(n-), from salutare ‘to greet’.

definitions.definition: A gesture or utterance made as a greeting.
definitions.example: He sent his salutations to the guests.

data.origin: Early 16th century: from French saluer, from Latin salutare ‘to greet’.

definitions.definition: To greet or show respect to, especially by raising the hand to the head.
definitions.example: Soldiers salute their officers.

definitions.definition: Making a show of being morally superior to others
definitions.example: His sanctimonious remarks about charity annoyed everyone.

data.origin: Late 18th century, from Greek skhēma 'form, figure'

definitions.definition: A diagrammatic representation; an outline or model
definitions.example: The database schema showed all the tables and their relationships.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin scrutinium

definitions.definition: Critical observation or examination
definitions.example: The documents were under close scrutiny by investigators.

definitions.definition: Fulfilling its function adequately; usable
definitions.example: The old coat was worn but still serviceable.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin sessio(n-)

definitions.definition: A period devoted to a particular activity
definitions.example: The band recorded three songs in one studio session.

data.origin: Old English scild, of Germanic origin

definitions.definition: A broad piece of armor for protection
definitions.example: The knight raised his shield against the attack.

definitions.definition: To protect from danger or harm
definitions.example: She shielded her eyes from the bright sun.

definitions.definition: An act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when alone
definitions.example: Hamlet's 'To be or not to be' is a famous soliloquy.

data.origin: Mid 17th century, from late Latin spontaneus

definitions.definition: The condition of being spontaneous
definitions.example: The spontaneity of children's play is delightful to watch.

data.origin: Mid 17th century, from late Latin spontaneus

definitions.definition: Natural and unconstrained
definitions.example: Her spontaneous laughter was infectious.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin structura

definitions.definition: A building or other constructed object
definitions.example: The Eiffel Tower is an impressive steel structure.

definitions.definition: To construct or arrange according to a plan
definitions.example: She structured her essay to build to a powerful conclusion.

definitions.definition: Existing in the mind but not immediately available to consciousness
definitions.example: Subconscious fears often influence our behavior.

definitions.definition: The part of the mind of which one is not fully aware
definitions.example: The memory was buried deep in his subconscious.

definitions.definition: The accomplishment of an aim or purpose
definitions.example: The project's success exceeded all expectations.

definitions.definition: Accomplishing a desired aim or result
definitions.example: The surgery was completely successful.

definitions.definition: A belief in supernatural influences

definitions.example: The food passes through the esophagus to reach the stomach.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French establissement

definitions.definition: The action of establishing something or being established
definitions.example: The establishment of the new school took three years.

definitions.definition: Spoken or done without preparation
definitions.example: Her extemporaneous speech impressed the audience.

definitions.definition: Happening by chance rather than intention
definitions.example: Our meeting was completely fortuitous.

definitions.definition: Resembling or consisting of small grains or particles
definitions.example: The sugar had a granular texture.

definitions.definition: Exaggerated dramatic behavior designed to attract attention
definitions.example: She threw a fit of histrionics when she didn't get her way.

definitions.definition: A mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual
definitions.example: One of his idiosyncrasies was always wearing odd socks.

definitions.definition: The process of putting a decision or plan into effect
definitions.example: The implementation of the new policy took several months.

definitions.definition: Emission of visible light by a body as a result of heating
definitions.example: The incandescence of the filament makes the bulb glow.

definitions.definition: Not clearly visible or attracting attention
definitions.example: He tried to make himself as inconspicuous as possible.

data.origin: Mid 17th century, from modern Latin infinitesimus

definitions.definition: Extremely small
definitions.example: The chances of error are infinitesimal.

definitions.definition: To bring oneself into favor with someone by flattering or trying to please them
definitions.example: He tried to ingratiate himself with the new boss.

definitions.definition: The action or process of integrating
definitions.example: The integration of different departments improved efficiency.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin machinatio

definitions.definition: A plot or scheme
definitions.example: The political machinations behind the scenes were complex.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Greek metamorphōsis

definitions.definition: A change of the form or nature of a thing into a completely different one
definitions.example: The metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a butterfly is fascinating.

definitions.definition: A large constellation on the celestial equator
definitions.example: Ophuchius is also known as the Serpent Bearer.

definitions.definition: Relating to, enacted by, or suitable for a parliament
definitions.example: The parliamentary debate lasted for hours.

definitions.definition: An act of spinning on one foot, typically with the raised foot touching the knee of the supporting leg
definitions.example: The ballerina performed a perfect pirouette.

definitions.definition: Occurring in several different forms
definitions.example: The polymorphic nature of the virus makes it hard to treat.

definitions.definition: Having more than one distinct form in the life cycle
definitions.example: Many fungi are polymorphic organisms.

definitions.definition: The occurrence of something in several different forms
definitions.example: Genetic polymorphism contributes to biodiversity.

definitions.definition: The provision of a single interface to entities of different types
definitions.example: Object-oriented programming relies heavily on polymorphism.

definitions.definition: A set of printed or written questions for gathering information
definitions.example: Participants were asked to complete a detailed questionnaire.

definitions.definition: Representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class
definitions.example: She was the quintessential professional, always punctual and prepared.

definitions.definition: The action of returning a military attack or bad treatment
definitions.example: The bombing was in retaliation for the earlier attack.

definitions.definition: Having or conveying undue or inappropriate interest in sexual matters
definitions.example: The novel was criticized for its salacious content.

data.origin: Mid 18th century, coined by Horace Walpole

definitions.definition: The occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way
definitions.example: Their meeting was pure serendipity.

definitions.definition: An act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when alone
definitions.example: Hamlet's 'To be or not to be' is a famous soliloquy.

definitions.definition: The condition of being spontaneous
definitions.example: The performance was praised for its spontaneity and energy.

definitions.definition: A belief not based on reason or knowledge
definitions.example: The superstition that breaking a mirror brings seven years of bad luck.

data.origin: Late 19th century, from Greek takhus + kardia

definitions.definition: An abnormally rapid heart rate
definitions.example: The patient was diagnosed with paroxysmal tachycardia.

definitions.definition: Having the same or nearly the same meaning
definitions.example: 'Happy' is synonymous with 'joyful' in many contexts.

definitions.definition: Visually attractive, especially in a quaint or charming way
definitions.example: The picturesque village attracted many artists.

definitions.definition: A person who is guided and supported by an older and more experienced person
definitions.example: The famous conductor's protege now leads his own orchestra.

data.origin: Middle English, from Old French tyrannie

definitions.definition: Cruel and oppressive government or rule
definitions.example: The revolution overthrew decades of tyranny.

definitions.definition: A member of a self-appointed group undertaking law enforcement without legal authority
definitions.example: The vigilante took matters into his own hands.

definitions.definition: Relating to such activity
definitions.example: Vigilante justice often leads to more problems.

definitions.definition: A device for increasing speed
definitions.example: He pressed the accelerator to pass the truck.

definitions.definition: A fierce or destructive attack
definitions.example: The army prepared for the enemy onslaught.

definitions.definition: An overwhelmingly large quantity
definitions.example: We faced an onslaught of customer complaints.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Old French encrochier

definitions.definition: Advance gradually beyond usual or acceptable limits
definitions.example: Urban development continues to encroach on wildlife habitats.

definitions.definition: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong
definitions.example: No human being is infallible.

definitions.definition: Never failing; always effective
definitions.example: They trusted in his infallible judgment.

definitions.definition: Past tense of massacre; to kill indiscriminately and brutally
definitions.example: The invading army massacred the villagers.

definitions.definition: Having been subjected to a massacre
definitions.example: The massacred bodies were buried in a mass grave.

data.origin: Late Middle English, from Latin apprehendere

definitions.definition: Past tense of apprehend; to arrest someone for a crime
definitions.example: The suspect was apprehended at the border.

definitions.definition: Understood or perceived
definitions.example: The apprehended danger turned out to be minimal.

data.origin: Middle English, archaic past participle of 'work'

definitions.definition: Past tense of work (archaic)
definitions.example: The blacksmith wrought the iron into a gate.

definitions.definition: Shaped by hammering or beating
definitions.example: The wrought iron balcony was beautifully crafted.

definitions.definition: Produced or brought about
definitions.example: The treaty wrought significant changes in foreign policy.

definitions.definition: The insertion of something of a different nature into something else
definitions.example: The interpolation of new scenes disrupted the film's continuity.

definitions.definition: A mathematical method of constructing new data points within known data points
definitions.example: The software uses linear interpolation to estimate values between measurements.

definitions.definition: To represent as or by an instance
definitions.example: The study instantiates this theory with concrete examples.

definitions.definition: In computing: to create an instance of a class
definitions.example: The program instantiates multiple objects during runtime.

definitions.definition: In mathematics: approaching a value or curve arbitrarily closely
definitions.example: The function approaches zero asymptotically.

definitions.definition: Existing or occurring at the same time
definitions.example: The dancers performed synchronous movements.
